    • Field Detail

      • DEFAULT_MIN_OKS_PER_OPERATION

        public static final int DEFAULT_MIN_OKS_PER_OPERATION
        By default we only need one successful store/delete operation requests for the operation to succeed.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DEFAULT_OPTIMAL_OKS_PER_OPERATION

        public static final int DEFAULT_OPTIMAL_OKS_PER_OPERATION
        By default we will try to call up to 2 stores (for PUT, DELETE) to keep things highly consistent.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DEFAULT_MAX_OKS

        public static final int DEFAULT_MAX_OKS
        By default we will try to call up to 3 stores (for PUT, DELETE) to allow new nodes to catch up when we are resizing the cluster or swapping out nodes; during transition we will usually have one more node

        Note: may be set higher if need be; only matters in cases where we actually do have more nodes available; so setting to, say, 100, should seldom hurt.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • withCallConfig

        public OperationConfig withCallConfig(CallConfig cc)

      • getCallConfig

        public CallConfig getCallConfig()

      • getMinimalOksToSucceed

        public int getMinimalOksToSucceed()
        Number of individual calls that must succeed for the write operation (that is, not used for read ops like GET or HEAD) to be considered "partially successful" (i.e. acceptable but not optimal).

      • getOptimalOks

        public int getOptimalOks()
        Number of individual calls that must succeed for the write operation (that is, not used for read ops like GET or HEAD) to be considered "fully successful". Used for determining whether to try making more calls after each individual success response received.

      • getMaxOks

        public int getMaxOks()
        Number of maximum number of successfull write calls (that is, not used for read ops like GET or HEAD) to try, in case we have more than usual number of replicas: typically only matters during transitions when new nodes are being added.

        It is common to define this to be 1 or 2 higher than getOptimalOks()

      • getPutOperationTimeoutMsecs

        public long getPutOperationTimeoutMsecs()
